I felt this might be helpful, forge build will be unable to resolve some imports due to wrong capitalization. I have corrected them below: In Setup.t.sol: import { ReLPContract } from "../../contracts/reLP/ReLPContract.sol"; // import { ReLPContract } from "../../contracts/relp/ReLPContract.sol"; In Periphery.t.sol: // import { UniV2LiquidityAMO } from "../../contracts/amo/UniV2LiquidityAMO.sol"; import { UniV2LiquidityAMO } from "../../contracts/amo/UniV2LiquidityAmo.sol"; // import { UniV3LiquidityAMO } from "../../contracts/amo/UniV3LiquidityAMO.sol"; import { UniV3LiquidityAMO } from "../../contracts/amo/UniV3LiquidityAmo.sol"; In MockRdpxEthPriceOracle.sol import { IUniswapV2Pair } from "../uniswap_V2/IUniswapV2Pair.sol"; // import { IUniswapV2Pair } from "../uniswap_v2/IUniswapV2Pair.sol"; (edited)

0xkazim 08/24/2023 12:57
can someone explain this line in writing call options in the docs to me ? Call option writers receive an upfront premium but pay call option buyers if the price of an asset increases beyond the strike price. If the difference in price exceeds the premiums earned, writers may incur a loss. how the writers may incure a loss ?
12:57
https://docs.dopex.io/option-fundamentals/option-parameters#writing-call-options
Option Parameters
12:58
is that mean when someone write(sell or become writer) a call option it mean he expect the price to become lower than the premium? Writing call options is useful for liquidity providers who expect the price of an asset to decrease or remain stable. It is not a risk-free strategy since losses are technically uncapped.
rafaelnicolau.eth 08/24/2023 12:59
https://twitter.com/DegenShaker/status/1693630294199280033 I think the answer to your question can be found in this thread
BlockChomper (@DegenShaker)
5/ The writer will receive a premium from buyer for the ability to purchase the contract. The writer will be at risk and can incur financial loss if the settlement price of the asset is lower than their written strike price at expiration and the buyer exercises the right to buy.

0xkazim 08/29/2023 12:44
hey @psytama did the %50 in the lines below mean the 50% of the %25 rpdx that we send to process a bond ? 50% of the rDPX provided for bonding is burnt from the Treasury Reserve and another 50% is sent as emissions to veDPX holders.
12:46
first we say the full amount of rdpx will be sent to the reserve and then we say we burn %50 rdpx in treasury reserve, how treasury reserve contains the rdpx if we send it all to the backing reserve ?
12:46
- The full amount of rDPX and 33% of the ETH provided (33% of 75% = 25%) is sent to the [Backing Reserve](https://www.notion.so/rDPX-V2-RI-b45b5b402af54bcab758d62fb7c69cb4?pvs=21) and used to mint dpxETH which is then paired with the rest of the ETH to LP on curve. - 50% of the rDPX provided for bonding is burnt from the [Treasury Reserve](https://www.notion.so/rDPX-V2-RI-b45b5b402af54bcab758d62fb7c69cb4?pvs=21) and another 50% is sent as emissions to veDPX holders. These percentages are variable and can be controlled by governance.

ElderberryLind 08/29/2023 13:26
Double check with psy but afaik the way it works is there is some amount of rDPX in the Dopex treasury right now (prior to any bonding occuring). When someone bonds, let's say $100 worth of value, $25 worth is rDPX. That bonded rDPX value is paired with $25 of bonded Eth and becomes LP for the rDPX/eth pool(backing reserve). Then, $25 worth of Treasury rDPX is taken from Treasury holdings and $12.5 dollars worth is burnt. And $12.5 worth of rDPX is given out to vedpx holders as rewards.
1
ElderberryLind
Double check with psy but afaik the way it works is there is some amount of rDPX in the Dopex treasury right now (prior to any bonding occuring). When someone bonds, let's say $100 worth of value, $25 worth is rDPX. That bonded rDPX value is paired with $25 of bonded Eth and becomes LP for the rDPX/eth pool(backing reserve). Then, $25 worth of Treasury rDPX is taken from Treasury holdings and $12.5 dollars worth is burnt. And $12.5 worth of rDPX is given out to vedpx holders as rewards.

0xMango 08/31/2023 18:16
The _amounts has to be an array here, because not everyones delegated weth balance will satisfy every amount. If a specific id has enough remaining weth to bond said amount, another id could possibly not satisfy the same amount. This way a user can bond many times using up many delegatees remaining weth, disregarding their active collateral.

I have a question please, it's more about the tokenomics than the code. My understanding is dpxETH is 1:1 with ETH. Q1: How is the value of the dpxETH determined? What if the price drops and we've called lowerDepeg and there are no more dpxEth to burn (or can they be minted via another way than upperDepeg function)? Q2: What incentive is there besides the fee for a user to addDelegate? My understanding (and tests) are that if nobody uses their eth, they just get their ETH back? tztokchad 09/02/2023 11:14
1. Since dpxeth is minted against 50% of bonded value in eth that is provided by the bonders, it would always maintain peg unless someone takes up a significant cost by purchasing dpxeth from the curve pool (and facing slippage and getting arbed), dumping it en masse (again facing slippage and getting arbed)
11:15
Along with a reasonable A factor it becomes very hard to depeg dpxeth
11:16
2. If they delegate their eth, they get to take a % of the bonded value of receipt tokens based on the fee they charge from rdpx holders.
tztokchad
2. If they delegate their eth, they get to take a % of the bonded value of receipt tokens based on the fee they charge from rdpx holders.

superman_i4g 09/02/2023 12:12
The perfect answer to this; 1. If use_safe_approve is true, it uses a safe approval method called safeApprove from TransferHelper. This method is used for tokens like USDT and requires resetting the approval to zero before each new approval. 2. If use_safe_approve is false, it uses the standard approve method from the token contract (assumed to implement the ERC-20 standard) to approve the specified address to spend the specified amount of tokens.
1
parsely 09/02/2023 12:14
Please correct my understanding if it is incorrect, but just sharing here so it may be helpful to others 1. User A -> addTodelegate , (NOTE: they can withdraw the unused portion of their deposit at any time -> but they will never get back in the withdraw function all their ETH if any was used.) 2. any user -> bondWithDelegate. using delegate id created by step 1. 3. A new bond id (RdpxV2Bond) is minted to User A (and the user but POV is depositor in this scenario). 4. After maturity of bond User A can redeem the receiptTokens from the bond minted in step 3 Step 3 takes into account the fee so the amount of tokens added include the fee portion no need claim it later. (edited)

parsely 09/02/2023 15:18
Sure: When a user calls bondWithdelegate The flow is: bondWithdelegate->_bondWithDelegate ->which calls _calculateAmounts as part of its flow. this sends in the fee of the delegate. _calculateAmounts returns 2 values both of which are used to create bonds, one for the user and one for the depositor. These return values take into account the fee that is set by the depositor: // account for delegate fee amount1 = (amount1 * (100e8 - _delegateFee)) / 1e10; amount2 = _amount - amount1; So when the bond is created the fee is already taken into account (edited)

address coin0 = dpxEthCurvePool.coins(0); The token at the zero index is set to the variable coin0
21:54
Your above mentioned check, checks if the token at the 0 index is weth, if it is, it sets a to be index 0 and b index 1, else, sets a as index 1 and b as index 0. The goal is to keep a to point to weth and b to be any other token, like rdpx

kim
how does one "Link to all referenced sections of code in GitHub"
dev0cloo 09/06/2023 11:50
You use the GitHub repo of the project. For any code you want to reference, you go to where it is in the repo, click the line the referenced code starts at and copy the url in your browser. It would look something like this "https://github.com/code-423n4/2023-08-dopex/blob/main/contracts/amo/UniV2LiquidityAmo.sol#L109" If the referenced code spans multiple lines, you just look for the line it ends at and modify the url to include those by adding "-L<line number code ends at>" to the end of the GitHub url. So the above example would be "https://github.com/code-423n4/2023-08-dopex/blob/main/contracts/amo/UniV2LiquidityAmo.sol#L109-L112" for some code that spans 4 lines

LokiThe5th 10/20/2023 12:01
imho it comes down to the fact that we are here to help any protocol/team secure their project. Yes, we do operate in an adversarial space. But we don't want the way we conduct ourselves to become a barrier to projects seeking C4's services. Acting unprofessionally only serves to deter teams from approaching us and ultimately harms our industry. Code quality is a subjective measure and we should assume positive intent from any team approaching C4. Have comments about code quality or think a codebase needs more extensive testing? Add it to your analysis; do it well enough and you will get paid for it. Once the contest is over we leave it all in the arena.
